data.source: State-level CO2 emissions from fossil fuel combustion; average weekly working hours from U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics; environmentalism measure from League of Conservation Voters; additional socio-economic indicators (e.g., GDP measures, population, energy production).
data.wave_or_subset: Balanced panel of all 50 U.S. states from 2007–2013.
data.notes: All continuous variables are log-transformed. Includes regional dummy variables (e.g., Midwest, South). Incorporates an environmentalism measure based on League of Conservation Voters scores. Models examine both scale (e.g., GDP per hour) and composition (e.g., GDP per capita) effects.

method.description: The study analyzes a balanced state-level panel (2007–2013) using fixed effects, random effects, and hybrid panel regression models to estimate the relationship between average working hours and CO2 emissions, distinguishing scale and composition effects while controlling for political, economic, and demographic covariates.
steps: Assemble state-level panel data for all 50 states, 2007–2013 (CO2 emissions from fossil fuel combustion; average weekly working hours; socio-economic and political covariates).
Construct variables capturing scale (e.g., GDP per hour) and composition (e.g., GDP per capita) effects.
Estimate panel regression models: fixed effects and random effects (Models 1–4) for scale and composition effects; additionally estimate hybrid models.
Include controls (e.g., employed population %, total population, energy production, manufacturing share of GDP, environmentalism scores) and regional dummies.
Conduct descriptive statistics, bivariate correlations, and sensitivity checks for influential cases.
Interpret coefficients (elasticities) for working hours and assess statistical significance and model fit.
method.models: Fixed effects and random effects panel regressions (log-log specifications); hybrid regression models; Models 1 & 3 (scale effects), Models 2 & 4 (composition effects).
method.outcome_variable: State-level carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel combustion (million metric tons).
method.independent_variables: Average weekly working hours per worker (key variable of interest); GDP per hour (scale), GDP per capita (composition).
method.control_variables: Employed population percentage, total population, energy production, manufacturing share of GDP, labor productivity, state environmentalism (League of Conservation Voters scores), regional dummies (e.g., Midwest, South).

results.summary: Across multiple panel models, longer average working hours are significantly associated with higher state-level CO2 emissions. Estimated elasticities for emissions with respect to working hours range around 0.63–0.67. Population size and energy production are positively related to emissions, while state environmentalism exhibits a significant negative association in composition-effect models. Results are robust to sensitivity checks.
